body: cc me
Also things like `Path`, `Command`, etc. It's common to want to be able to create sets of even somewhat exotic objects.

I’m imagining a tool which produces a massive table where each column is a trait and each row is a struct or enum, with each cell shaded appropriately for whether there is an implementation (under any constraints) of the trait for the type.

For items in `collections`, and among the traits Clone, Default, FromIterator, Extendable, Hash, PartialEq, Eq, PartialOrd, and Show, here's what's still missing:
- `EnumSet` is missing a bunch. I've held off on implementing these because I wasn't sure it was sticking around since we have `bitflags!` now
- `PriorityQueue` is missing Hash/PartialEq/Eq/Show/PartialOrd. I'm not sure if it's currently possible to implement these
- `BTree` is missing Default/FromIterator/Extendable/Hash
`std::path::Path` doesn’t implement `Show` #15625

If #16850 gets merged, the only things remaining are those that @nham mentioned.

In particular, `semver`, `url` and `uuid` are deprecated and will be removed from the standard library.
Does this need any more work done?

Things that still need to be done:

What nham said:

> For items in collections, and among the traits Clone, Default, FromIterator, Extendable, Hash, PartialEq, Eq, PartialOrd, and Show, here's what's still missing:
> - EnumSet is missing a bunch. I've held off on implementing these because I wasn't sure it was sticking around since we have bitflags! now
> - PriorityQueue is missing Hash/PartialEq/Eq/Show/PartialOrd. I'm not sure if it's currently possible to implement these
> - BTree is missing Default/FromIterator/Extendable/Hash

What SimonSapin said:

> std::path::Path doesn’t implement Show #15625

My BTree reimpl adds all of these.

I agree that it would be impractical (not impossible!) for PriorityQueue to provide these methods, except for Show assuming there doesn't need to be a "canonical" or "expected" output.

> My BTree reimpl adds all of these.

For reference: The corresponding pull request is #17334.

> std::path::Path doesn’t implement Show #15625

Actually, there is a reason for that. Since `Path` can contain bytes that are not valid UTF-8, `Show for Path` (assuming we want `format!` not to fail) needs either be lossy (this is what `Path::display` does) or use some kind of escaping. The point of `Path::display` is to force users to be explicit about using something lossy.

I think a lossy `Show` would be fine. (It should be documented though.)

2014-09-25 18:27 GMT-04:00 Simon Sapin notifications@github.com:

> std::path::Path doesn’t implement Show #15625
> https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/15625
> 
> Actually, there is a reason for that. Since Path can contain bytes that
> are not valid UTF-8, Show for Path (assuming we want format! not to fail)
> needs either be lossy (this is what Path::display does) or use some kind
> of escaping. The point of Path::display is to force users to be explicit
> about using something lossy.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/15294#issuecomment-56893469.
Note that `.to_string()` is provided for anything with `Show`, and having that be lossy sounds risky to me.

It will not be lossy in most use cases though.

2014-09-25 18:44 GMT-04:00 Simon Sapin notifications@github.com:

> Note that .to_string() is provided for anything with Show, and having
> that be lossy sounds risky to me.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/15294#issuecomment-56895010.

> It will not be lossy in most use cases though.

Which makes it especially dangerous! I’ll look alright in a few test cases, and a bug will go unnoticed.

I think we should consider:
- Decoupling `to_string` from `Show`
- Explicitly saying that `Show` is for debugging, and thus may be lossy
In particular, the serialization infrastructure is a better fit for non-lossy serialization, and has its own deriving capabilities.

> Explicitly saying that Show is for debugging, and thus may be lossy

Perhaps debugging should be separated from converting things to strings in production code? Python has `repr()` and `str()`.

What is "the serialization infrastructure"? The `Encodable` trait? That sound completely different from `Show`, to me.

@SimonSapin 

> Perhaps debugging should be separated from converting things to strings in production code? Python has repr() and str().

Maybe so. I'm wondering what guarantees, if any, should be provided by a string conversion? See below.

> What is "the serialization infrastructure"? The Encodable trait? That sound completely different from Show, to me.

Yes, and that's the intent -- `Show` would be for debugging or display, but not for round-trippable serialization purposes. We have `libserialize` for that.

In any case, I think we need to be more clear about the global expectations on both `Show` and `to_string`. I see three use cases to cover:
- Trivial inspection/debugging/display, which might be lossy; `Show`
- More "polished", non-lossy but often manually-tweaked string conversion: `to_string`
- Round-trippable serialization: `Encodable`/`Decodable`

Do you see a distinct set of use cases? Or a different ideal mapping to traits/methods?

cc @alexcrichton

> More "polished", non-lossy but often manually-tweaked string conversion: to_string 

I’m currently [using `Show` for this in rust-url](https://github.com/servo/rust-url/blob/29f70a47230c2aa736e263977247c786e0b2c243/src/format.rs). Different components of the URL know how to format themselves, and may be formatted independently. But when formatting an full URL, multiple components are involved and `fmt` methods call each other. Although the end user convenience method is `to_string`, I want the implementation (split in multiple methods) to write chunks of bytes (though it really should be Unicode text) to a shared stream rather than allocate a bunch of intermediate strings.

I don’t see how `Encodable` would work for this. As far as I understand, the `Encoder` chooses the serialization format, not the implementer of `Encodable`.

@SimonSapin 

You can implement `Encodable` for a specific `Encoder` if you want to pin things down. But this does feel like overkill for the use case you're suggesting.

So the counter-proposal is to keep `Show` as-is (and stipulate that its output must be utf-8 and non-lossy) and add a separate trait -- say, `Inspect` -- that is still utf-8 but may be lossy? And still have `Show` provide `to_string`? We could add `#[deriving(Inspect)]` as well.

That could be sensible, and it would make sense to give a blanket impl of `Inspect` for everything that is `Show` -- in which case, this would be a pretty minor change.

Yes, having `Show` and `Inspect` like this sounds reasonable.

(Require valid UTF-8 is fairly orthogonal. It would allow skipping [this check that may `fail!`](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/2550243b4183783e463fbb0bc141ab77f2898e64/src/libstd/fmt.rs#L465). See [Unicode streams](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/57).)

Decoupling Show and to_string sounds like a good idea. To me the name "Show" does not imply non-lossiness, I added it to Path because it seemed like a big omission. Also CString is doing a lossy utf conversion in its Show implementation also.

edit: actually "Show" to me really implies lossiness, it is a very vague term that seems to suggest it'll do whatever is needed to "Show" this item. If we were to enforce strict utf conversion for this then I think the trait should be renamed.

Re naming: I’m fine with `Show` being the one for lossy debugging (what @aturon called `Inspect`) as long as there is also something else based on streams to implement `to_string()`.

Now, which one should `format!()` and friends (meaning the family of macros that use formatting strings with `{}`) refer to? Could it be both?
cc me

> I'm not entirely sold on the usefulness of a semi-polished, but slightly manual, and still non-lossy middle ground between full-on serialization and debugging.

I don’t understand how serialization is applicable here. How can I use `Encodable` to serialize not to something like JSON, but to string (or stream of text) in a format determined by the implementer of the `Encodable` trait? E.g. an URL is something like `http://example.com`, not `{"scheme": "http", "host": "example.com", ...}`

I would imagine that if you know that your type can be perfectly encoded as a string then you invoke `encode_str` and `decode_str` with your own parsing as appropriate. With @aturon's multidispatch proposal, and depending on the design of `Encodable`, you could specify a different method of encoding per-encoder (if the encoder remains a type parameter on the trait).

It would also be useful to have a "debugging" serialization (e.g. used in `assert_eq!`) of `String` and `&str` that is not just the string itself. Currently, `println!("{}", vec!["a", "b, c", ""])` returns `[a, b, c, ]` which can be confusing.
We have BTreeMap and BTreeSet impling all the common things. So I think this issue in now just "do #17534". Can be closed?
What about `EnumSet`?
What's it missing? Ord/PartialOrd?
Ok. EnumSet is Ord+PartialOrd now. Anything else?
I think this is all and this can be closed.
Almost no iterators (`Map`, `FlatMap`, `MoveItems`, etc.) implement `Clone`, which can be annoying. I’m not sure how much sense this makes, but I’d like to be able to clone iterators sometimes.
Iterators like `Map` can't implement `Clone` because they use the traditional boxed closures.

It would be completely unsound for `iter_mut` to be cloneable. Cloning an `into_iter`ator also seems vaguely unsound to me. It couldn't be lazy, at very least. It would have to completely clone the underlying structure, at which point... what have we accomplished over just cloning before/after the iteration? That only leaves `iter`ators, which could probably be cloned soundly. Although honestly this seems like more of an argument for providing `prev` and `prev_back` on such iterators.

Can you provide some concrete usecases?

It's not possible to provide `prev` to most iterators without adding overhead. It also wouldn't be safe on mutable iterators. Cloning iterators is useful and is how `cycle` is implemented, but for the closure-based adaptors it would require moving to unboxed closures.

@thestinger I was only suggesting adding `prev` for immutable iterators over collections. Almost all of them could provide this trivially, as far as I can tell. You just increment `nelems` and move the pointer in the other direction (which you know how to do if you're double-ended). You do have to add some extra logic for seeing if you've `prev`'d off the end of the structure, but that should only add complexity for `prev`.

No, double-ended doesn't imply the ability to move the iterator in the reverse direction. A vector iterator has a pointer to either end of the remaining range and would need 4 pointers if it could be expanded again via `prev`. The same thing can be accomplished without overhead by cloning the iterator before advancing it and then restoring the state, as `cycle` does.

Move-iterators are safe to clone, e.g. `Vec<T>.into_iter()` would clone by non-destructively traversing to get `&`s (which is actually something we could expose externally) and pushing onto a new `Vec` and `into_iter`-ing that.

(I'm sure it would be difficult to write clone implementations for some move-iterators, but the common ones probably aren't so bad.)
@thestinger Ah, I mistakenly assumed the Vec iterator had a reference to the source slice.

Note: I've created a [discuss topic](http://discuss.rust-lang.org/t/show-to-string-and-guidelines/590) to address the questions around `Show` raised in this thread. I'd like to write an RFC to nail this down, but first wanted to solicit community feelings on the topic.

Given that this issue is vague, and it seems like all of the specific things mentioned here have been done, I'm giving this a close. If anyone knows of any other things that are missing, let's add them, but I don't find this ticket to be super actionable right now.
